summary: I have a proposition to make.
body:
I have a proposition to make.

If Hulk is The strongest Avenger, then Carol Danvers can only be The gayest Avenger and you can’t change my mind.

summary: The line where Carol asks Fury, "You have 3 names??" because she doesn't remember how human names work yet is especially funny...
body: The line where Carol asks Fury, “You have 3 names??” because she doesn’t remember how human names work yet is especially funny if you imagine her confusion when she remembers her whole name is Carol Susan Jane Danvers. “FURY I HAVE AN EXTRA ONE WHAT DOES THIS MEAN?!”

reblog.comment: The line where Carol asks Fury, “You have 3 names??” because she doesn’t remember how human names work yet is especially funny if you imagine her confusion when she remembers her whole name is Carol Susan Jane Danvers. “FURY I HAVE AN EXTRA ONE WHAT DOES THIS MEAN?!”

summary: The relentless negativity towards Captain Marvel fills me with nothing but contempt for humanity and a feeling of shame and...
body:
The relentless negativity towards Captain Marvel fills me with nothing but contempt for humanity and a feeling of shame and despair.

Just shut the fuck up. God. I’m done. I’m blocking every single bit of negativity I see. I don’t need that shit in my life. Let me enjoy my fucking movies without an onslaught of bullshit for years on end.

summary: Captain Marvel spoilers beneath the cut. And not even really spoilers, since the cut doesn’t work on mobile? Is that still true?...
body:
Captain Marvel spoilers beneath the cut. And not even really spoilers, since the cut doesn’t work on mobile? Is that still true? Anyway, just some thoughts. 

The movie isn’t perfect technically – the first couple of scenes could have been done much better in other ways and some of the CGI needs work (the Coulson de-aging was distracting) – and this will get jumped on by the nerdbros. The tone was a bit all over the place in parts as well. 

DOESN’T MATTER. The movie was so much fun. I cheered, I teared up, I clapped and hollered at the screen along with the rest oft he theatre, and I came out of this thing shipping Carol / Maria SO HARD that I can’t even stand it. 

(Also, there is a scene that is beat-for-beat from a sequence in Chapter 11 of Green Man From Outer Space. It’s been posted to Patreon for months now, dammit, so I can prove that I wrote it long before I saw the movie. I consider it validation of my sense of humour. XD )

summary: I've just been to see Captain Marvel and I don't want to say anything too spoilery but I feel like Carol and Steve would get on...
body:
I’ve just been to see Captain Marvel and I don’t want to say anything too spoilery but I feel like Carol and Steve would get on a bit too well and would cause the rest of the team to go grey.

Like she would fit into his and Thor’s soft Frat Bros dynamic so well. They would go into biker bars and drink enough beer to kill lesser mortals. And if anyone said anything then all of their ‘Fight Me, Bitch’ instincts would kick in! Just think of the havoc fun they could have (that Tony/Fury would pay for with a half impressed half dispointed stare)!

Also if anyone wants to do a manip of Carol in her grunge gear and Steve and Thor in casual clothes that would be great.

blog.name: courtneysmovieblog
blog.title: Courtney's Movie Blog
blog.description: I review movies, new and old!

summary: The Marvelous “Captain Marvel”
title: The Marvelous “Captain Marvel”
body:
Before I begin this review, I want to know: what happened to the Marvel fandom – or all fandoms, for that matter?  

How did we get infected with so much vitriol that there always has to be some kind of backlash for everything that comes out – especially when it comes to female characters?  Whether it’s bashing Sharon Carter just because you’re a Stucky fan, bashing Jane Foster just because she’s “boring,” or troll-bombing review sites for Captain Marvel just because Brie Larson is an outspoken feminist…I could go on.

It’s no coincidence that the same critics that are dissing Captain Marvel, the first female-led Marvel movie, are of the conservative persuasion.  While they dismiss the film as “lackluster” and “mediocre”, they also can’t help sneaking it a dig about it trying to “advertise a feminist agenda.”

These guys weren’t watching the same movie I was watching.  Because Captain Marvel is not only the Marvel superheroine movie we’ve been waiting for since Wonder Woman, it’s another much-needed pick-me-up for those still traumatized by Infinity War.

We are first introduced to her as “Vers”, an amnesiac fighter for the Starforce, led by her mentor, Yon-Rugg (Jude Law).  During a battle with the Skrulls, a shapeshifting alien race, Vers crash-lands on Earth, where she meets the young(er) SHIELD agent Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson).  

As the two of them team up to track down the Skrulls that followed her, she begins to regain her memories of her previous life on Earth as Air Force pilot Carol Danvers.  But her identity isn’t the only secret that the Kree have been hiding from her…

Brie Larson’s performance is way better than the trailers would have you believe.  Carol/Vers has all the heart of Steve Rogers and all the snark of Tony Stark.  Her determination and compassion will make you root for her no matter what gender you are.  Additionally, she has a wonderful rapport not only with Jackson’s Fury but also Carol’s fellow pilot and best friend, Marie Rambeau (Lashana Lynch).  It’s their relationship in particular that’s the highlight of the film, perhaps because it replaces the usual angsty romance of other superhero movies.

Ben Mendelsohn is also great as Talos, the leader of the Skrulls.  He may be currently typecast as villains, but this role is nothing that you’ve come to expect from him.  I can’t say more without spoilers.

Easily the best character in the whole movie is Goose the cat.  ‘Nough said.

The film serves as a prequel of sorts to The Avengers.  Die-hard fans will squeal over the return of Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg) and several other Marvel easter egg.  But nothing will make them more emotional than the beautiful tribute to the late Stan Lee in the opening credits. 

Since the film takes place in the ‘90s, there are countless fun references to that decade: Blockbusters, Radio Shacks, slower internet, and of course the music.  It’s all good fun, though I wish the filmmakers would have given Carol a better song to kick ass than “I’m Just A Girl.”  Seriously, Thor gets “The Immigrant Song” and Carol gets that?!  Lame.

Is the film perfect?  No.  It’s hard to measure up to Wonder Woman because the fact is DC got there first.  But even if the film was as bland as the trolls are accusing it of being, that shouldn’t matter.  Even Marvel’s less-than-stellar movies have been enjoyable.  Seriously, guys, do we go to these movies for perfection or entertainment?

The so-called controversy over Captain Marvel is proof that the only people ruining Marvel fandoms – and all the other fandoms – are the whiny, toxic fanboys that won’t let anyone else enjoy anything.  If they can’t accept Captain Marvel in the Marvel-verse, they don’t belong in this fandom.

9 out of 10

9 out of 10

We are first introduced to her as “Vers”, an amnesiac fighter for the Starforce, led by her mentor, Yon-Rugg (Jude Law).  During a battle with the Skrulls, a shapeshifting alien race, Vers crash-lands on Earth, where she meets the young(er) SHIELD agent Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson).  

As the two of them team up to track down the Skrulls that followed her, she begins to regain her memories of her previous life on Earth as Air Force pilot Carol Danvers.  But her identity isn’t the only secret that the Kree have been hiding from her…

Brie Larson’s performance is way better than the trailers would have you believe.  Carol/Vers has all the heart of Steve Rogers and all the snark of Tony Stark.  Her determination and compassion will make you root for her no matter what gender you are.  Additionally, she has a wonderful rapport not only with Jackson’s Fury but also Carol’s fellow pilot and best friend, Marie Rambeau (Lashana Lynch).  It’s their relationship in particular that’s the highlight of the film, perhaps because it replaces the usual angsty romance of other superhero movies.

Ben Mendelsohn is also great as Talos, the leader of the Skrulls.  He may be currently typecast as villains, but this role is nothing that you’ve come to expect from him.  I can’t say more without spoilers.

Easily the best character in the whole movie is Goose the cat.  ‘Nough said.

The film serves as a prequel of sorts to The Avengers.  Die-hard fans will squeal over the return of Agent Coulson (Clark Gregg) and several other Marvel easter egg.  But nothing will make them more emotional than the beautiful tribute to the late Stan Lee in the opening credits. 

Since the film takes place in the ‘90s, there are countless fun references to that decade: Blockbusters, Radio Shacks, slower internet, and of course the music.  It’s all good fun, though I wish the filmmakers would have given Carol a better song to kick ass than “I’m Just A Girl.”  Seriously, Thor gets “The Immigrant Song” and Carol gets that?!  Lame.

Is the film perfect?  No.  It’s hard to measure up to Wonder Woman because the fact is DC got there first.  But even if the film was as bland as the trolls are accusing it of being, that shouldn’t matter.  Even Marvel’s less-than-stellar movies have been enjoyable.  Seriously, guys, do we go to these movies for perfection or entertainment?

The so-called controversy over Captain Marvel is proof that the only people ruining Marvel fandoms – and all the other fandoms – are the whiny, toxic fanboys that won’t let anyone else enjoy anything.  If they can’t accept Captain Marvel in the Marvel-verse, they don’t belong in this fandom.

9 out of 10

summary: Saw Captain Marvel (no spoilers)
body:
Saw Captain Marvel (no spoilers)

I have to say, I loved it. Carl was badass, and hers and Fury’s friendship was nice to watch. But what I loved most about it was that, in the area I live, a mostly misogynistic society, I heard men fucking screaming every time Carol did something badass. They also cheered for Fury’s and Coulson’s entrance, but they went apeshit at Carol glowing the fuck up and kicking ass. And I loved that.
